subject: Re: [junit] Testing Methods with Dates WAS: Testing Methods with Random Numbers
msgSnippet: ... Cool! ... That certain is a good timer abstraction & implementation, but it is not what we needed. We needed the current date & Time, not a timed period.
messageBody:
Russell Gold wrote:

>On 7/12/05, Andrew McDonagh <andrew.mcdonagh@...> wrote:
>
>
>>Instead of code using Java's System.currentTimeInMillis() method
>>directly, they get the time via an abstract factory. The production code
>>concrete factory does the usual System.currentTimeInMillis() whereas the
>>tests use a Test Concrete Factory that is preconfigured to always return
>>the same value.
>>
>>
>>public interface SystemTimeFactory {
>> long currentTimeInMillis();
>> long currentTimeInSeconds();
>>}
>>
>>
>>
>
>Yes, we seem to have found the same general approach.
>

Cool!

>But I think this
>can be improved as more than a simple facade - most code that wants to
>get time has a higher level idea that just looking at raw time. So you
>can use instead something like:
>
>public interface Timer {
> void start();
> void stop();
> void reset();
> long secondsElapsed();
>}
>
>The implementation, both for production and test are obvious and
>simple, and the additional level of indirection is easily justified by
>the abstraction.
>
>
>
>
That certain is a good timer abstraction & implementation, but it is not
what we needed.
We needed the current date & Time, not a timed period.
